narrative: Over the past two weeks, I have never had little interest or pleasure in doing things. I have felt down, depressed, or hopeless more than half the days. I have had trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much more than half the days. I have never felt tired or having little energy. I have never had poor appetite or overeaten. I have never felt bad about myself — or that I am a failure or have let myself or my family down. I have never had trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television. I have never moved or spoken so slowly that other people could have noticed. I have never had thoughts that I would be better off dead or of hurting myself in some way.

Over the past two weeks, I have found myself grappling with a persistent lack of interest or pleasure in activities that once held my attention. More than half of these days have been overshadowed by feelings of being down, depressed, or hopeless, casting a lingering shadow that I struggle to shake. Nights have been particularly challenging, with me battling either to fall asleep or to remain asleep, only to find myself sleeping too much when I do finally manage to rest. Strikingly, however, I have not suffered from fatigue or felt drained of energy. Throughout this difficult period, my appetite has remained steady, neither waning nor driving me to overeat. Rather unexpectedly, I have maintained a neutral self-view, not burdened by feelings of failure or self-reproach, nor carrying the weight of letting myself or my family down. My concentration has also remained sharp, allowing me to engage with reading or watching television without struggle. In my interactions, I have moved and spoken at a normal pace, avoiding drawing any unwanted attention from others. Encouragingly, despite the emotional turmoil, I have never succumbed to thoughts of self-harm or considered the world better off without me. Even amidst the gloom, I hold onto a sense of resilience, determined to navigate through this tough time without spiraling into deeper despair.

Sleep eludes me as well, with nights spent tossing and turning or, at times, oversleeping in an attempt to escape the relentless fatigue. I wake feeling more drained than rested. It seems that more than half the days, energy is a scarce resource, leaving me weary and worn. Food, too, has lost its normal rhythm. I swing between a lack of appetite and moments of overeating, each extreme troubling me more than half the days. Each reflection in the mirror only deepens the conviction that I am a failure, letting down myself and, perhaps more painfully, my family. Nearly every day, self-reproach and guilt loop relentlessly in my mind. Concentration has become almost impossible for me. Once simple tasks, like reading the newspaper or watching television, often slip beyond reach as my focus fractures time and again. Though I have never moved or spoken so slowly that it would draw others' attention, the drag of despair is painfully evident within. Several days have been particularly dark, with thoughts creeping in that I might be better off dead or thoughts of self-harm disturbing my fragile peace. Despite these silent struggles, I carry on, living through each day with the hope for a glimmer of change or relief.

Over the past two weeks, my days have blended together into a blur of monotony and struggle. More often than not, I have found little joy or interest in activities that once brought me pleasure. The weight of feeling down, depressed, or hopeless presses heavily on me, coloring more than half of my days with a dull, oppressive gray. Sleep has become a battleground for me, with troubles falling asleep or staying asleep, and then on other nights, sleeping far too much, never finding a restful balance. Each day, I have felt an overwhelming fatigue and a lack of energy, making even the simplest tasks feel insurmountable. My relationship with food has wavered between poor appetite and overeating, neither bringing comfort or satisfaction. A sense of self-doubt has plagued me, as feelings of failure and disappointment creep in several days. I wrestle with the notion of having let myself or my family down, struggling to find worth or purpose. Concentration slips through my fingers like sand, turning reading the newspaper or watching television into daunting tasks. On many days, my movements and speech come slowly, a heaviness noticed by others, as if I am wading through a thick fog. In the darkest moments, my thoughts have drifted toward the belief that perhaps being dead, or causing self-harm, might be an escape from the relentless pain. This internal battle leaves me grasping for hope and a way back to the light.

Deep within, I carry a heavy burden of self-doubt, feeling as though I have failed or disappointed myself and others more days than I would like to admit. My concentration falters, making focusing on simple tasks like reading the newspaper or watching television a daunting challenge on more than half the days. The changes in me are not just internal. My movements and speech are often so lethargic and slow that those around me may notice nearly every day. In the darkest moments, thoughts of self-harm or the belief that the world might be better off without me have surfaced with alarming frequency. Each day has been a struggle, navigating a terrain filled with emotional and physical hurdles.

Over the past two weeks, I have navigated a landscape engulfed in shadow, where the vibrant hues of daily life have lost their brilliance. Each morning, I awoke to a world steeped in gray, the thought of engaging with the day ahead devoid of allure or joy. The feeling of despondency settled in like an unwelcome guest, whispering a litany of hopelessness that echoed in the corners of my mind nearly every day. The nights offered little respite, as sleep became a capricious companion. I lay awake, thoughts swirling, drifting into slumber only to awaken too soon, or sometimes retreating into sleep's embrace for far longer than intended. Fatigue clung to me, a constant reminder of the energy that once fueled passions and pursuits now diminished to mere embers. Eating became either a neglected necessity or an overzealous escape, as my appetite betrayed its natural rhythm. Guilt and self-reproach carved deep furrows in my heart, each day burdened by the heavy cloak of perceived failure, convinced that family and personal expectations lay shattered at my feet. Concentration eluded me, words on a page or scenes on a screen fading into an indistinct blur of disinterest. Movements and words slowed as if submerged in a viscous malaise, drawing curious glances or worried inquiries from those around. Yet, it was the pervasive, haunting notion—the fleeting, dangerous belief that all might be simpler without existence—that loomed most ominously. More than once, I contemplated the comfort of silence over the cacophony of despair, the shadow of such thoughts casting a long, chilling reflection over more than half the days.

Over the past two weeks, I have wandered through days filled with an overwhelming sense of disinterest, finding little pleasure in activities I once enjoyed. Nearly every day, I have faced the burdensome weight of feeling down, depressed, or hopeless, which has cast a persistent shadow over my daily life. Battling restlessness, I have struggled with sleep, either finding it difficult to fall or stay asleep, or alternatively, sleeping excessively, leaving a constant shroud of fatigue. The exhaustion has seeped into the core of my being, causing a notable lack of energy to engage with the world. My eating habits have also been irregular, as my appetite has swung from near absence to overindulgence, reflecting my inner turmoil. Despite these challenges, I have maintained a steady belief in my personal worth, never succumbing to feelings of failure or shame regarding myself or my family. However, concentration has been another casualty, with me finding it hard to focus on tasks like reading the newspaper or watching television more often than not. My movements and speech have slowed to a pace that others couldn't help but notice, marking the visible signs of my internal struggle. Most concerning, however, have been the intrusive thoughts that continuously surface, whispering that it would be better to not exist or to inflict harm upon myself. These thoughts have lingered nearly every day, underscoring the urgent need for hope and healing in my life. Yet, through the haze of these emotions, an unyielding flicker of resilience remains.

Over the past two weeks, I have navigated through a haze of disinterest and lethargy that seemed to wrap around every corner of daily life. Gone are the days of easily finding joy in simple activities. Instead, feelings of being down and hopeless weigh heavily and relentlessly, refusing to lift. Nights have become battlegrounds, where I wrestle with the elusive nature of sleep. When sleep does come, it either feels like too little or too much. Throughout many days, I struggle with a pervasive tiredness that seems to seep into my bones, making simple tasks feel monumental. Meals are no refuge; my appetite is as inconsistent as my mood, swinging from barely touching food to mindlessly overeating. Each day feels like a fresh inventory of self-doubt, where I grapple with feelings of inadequacy and failure that stem from within and reach into family expectations. Concentration becomes a rare visitor, slipping away when I attempt to read a newspaper or follow a storyline on television. Though outwardly, I never move or speak in a slowed manner that others might notice, internally, the heaviness impacts every thought and action. The darkest of moments bring uninvited, troubling thoughts of self-harm, casting a shadow over nearly every attempt to find some semblance of peace. In this bleak landscape, I stand, quietly hoping for a turning point, a moment where light will break through the pervasive gloom and lead toward healing.

There have been several days when he has felt trapped in a fog of despair, grappling with feelings of being down, depressed, or hopeless. As night falls, restless nights have become the norm, with him either tossing and turning or sleeping excessively nearly every night. The days are marked by an overwhelming fatigue, a lack of energy that sweeps over life more often than not. His relationship with food has also changed, swinging between a poor appetite and bouts of overeating on most days. Deep within, he carries a heavy burden of self-doubt, feeling as though he has failed or disappointed himself and others more days than he would like to admit. Concentration falters, making focusing on simple tasks like reading the newspaper or watching television a daunting challenge on more than half the days. The changes in him are not just internal. Movements and speech are often so lethargic and slow that those around may notice nearly every day. In the darkest moments, thoughts of self-harm or the belief that the world might be better off without him have surfaced with alarming frequency. Each day has been a struggle, navigating a terrain filled with emotional and physical hurdles.

Over the past two weeks, he has navigated a landscape engulfed in shadow, where the vibrant hues of daily life have lost their brilliance. Each morning, he awoke to a world steeped in gray, the thought of engaging with the day ahead devoid of allure or joy. The feeling of despondency settled in like an unwelcome guest, whispering a litany of hopelessness that echoed in the corners of his mind nearly every day. The nights offered little respite, as sleep became a capricious companion. He lay awake, thoughts swirling, drifting into slumber only to awaken too soon, or sometimes retreating into sleep's embrace for far longer than intended. Fatigue clung to him, a constant reminder of the energy that once fueled passions and pursuits now diminished to mere embers. Eating became either a neglected necessity or an overzealous escape, as his appetite betrayed its natural rhythm. Guilt and self-reproach carved deep furrows in his heart, each day burdened by the heavy cloak of perceived failure, convinced that family and personal expectations lay shattered at his feet. Concentration eluded him, words on a page or scenes on a screen fading into an indistinct blur of disinterest. Movements and words slowed as if submerged in a viscous malaise, drawing curious glances or worried inquiries from those around. Yet, it was the pervasive, haunting notion—the fleeting, dangerous belief that all might be simpler without existence—that loomed most ominously. More than once, he contemplated the comfort of silence over the cacophony of despair, the shadow of such thoughts casting a long, chilling reflection over more than half the days.

The exhaustion has seeped into the core of his being, causing a notable lack of energy to engage with the world. Eating habits have also been irregular, as his appetite has swung from near absence to overindulgence, reflecting the inner turmoil. Despite these challenges, he has maintained a steady belief in personal worth, never succumbing to feelings of failure or shame regarding himself or his family. Most concerning, however, have been the intrusive thoughts that continuously surface, whispering that it would be better to not exist or to inflict harm upon himself. These thoughts have lingered nearly every day, underscoring the urgent need for hope and healing in his life. Yet, through the haze of these emotions, an unyielding flicker of resilience remains.

In this bleak landscape, he stood, quietly hoping for a turning point, a moment where light would break through the pervasive gloom and lead toward healing.
